maps.text: Map of the Iberian Peninsula highlighting the region of the ancient Kingdom of León before its unification with Castile in (Atlas Nacional de España). The delimited area is shown approximately to provide the reader with a clearer understanding

common.text:
The kings of León studied on this page are descendants of Alfonso III, el Magno, king of Asturias, who transferred his capital to León (Medieval Lands, ). The relationship between the kings of León and the Asturian kings is not hypothetical, unlike the supposed connection between the Visigothic and Asturian kings (History Tracers, ).

When discussing the kings of León in his lineage book, Count Don Pedro does not differentiate between the Asturian and León kings, considering them all as kings of León (Nobiliário Conde Dom Pedro, , pp. 1 - 5).

Knowledge never stops, and here we are not presenting the entire history of the Visigoth kings. To learn more about them, in addition to the chronicles and papers we mention, we suggest visiting the site Medieval Lands (Medieval Lands, ).

history.text:
The history begins with Ordoño II, son of Alfonso III. We follow chronicles contemporary to the kings to present the genealogy as close to the facts as possible.

Regarding the ancestors of Alfonso III, the Great, Count Don Pedro suggests a lineage (Nobiliário Conde Dom Pedro, , pp. 1 - 5) which is incompatible with the chronicles, thus we treat it as hypothetical. On the other hand, Medieval Lands follows the ancestors according to the chronicles (Medieval Lands, )
The life of Ordoño II is relatively well documented in the publication about the Monastery of Sahagún
Mentioned in a document dated <htdate0>, Medieval Lands raises the hypothesis that this document could have been written to the proposed date

source.page: Diplomata et Chartae, Volumen I, Fascicvlvs I, pp. 7 - 8

There is no doubt that Ramiro is the son of Ordoño. This is confirmed in the Sampiro Chronicle and also in a document from the County of Portucalense. However, the documents diverge on the identity of his mother

source.page: Diplomata et Chartae, Volumen I, Fascicvlvs I, pp. 7 - 8

history.text:
When he began to rule the Kingdom of León, Ramiro ruled as Ramiro II (Medieval Lands, ). He was responsible for expanding the kingdom's borders (Medieval Lands, ). Among the wars he fought, the war against the Muslims is particularly notable. When we read the report of Count Don Pedro about a supposed relationship between Ramiro II and a Muslim woman named Artiga, we must highlight (Nobiliário Conde Dom Pedro, , pp. 4, 111 - 116):

  • The details of the description.
  • The omission of the second marriage of Ramiro II with Urraca.
  • The mention of Sancho as the son of Adosinda (Aldara) and not his mother Urraca.

The lack of documentation to confirm the marriage of Ramiro II has led different researchers to seek documentation that can indirectly confirm this marriage, known as the legend of Gaia (Rei, Antonio, ; Geneall, ; Rodrigues de Oliveira, Natália S. T., )

What is known about the war against the Muslims is that Ramiro II won in , but the following year he suffered a significant defeat, leading him to sign a neutrality agreement with the Muslims (Medieval Lands, ).

Ramiro II had documented children from two marriages. The first wife was named Adosinda (Lacarra, José M., , pp. 238; Medieval Lands, ). The second wife was named Urraca, according to the Codex Roda (Lacarra, José M., , pp. 236,238; Medieval Lands, )

Portuguese chronicles, centuries after the death of Ramiro II, mentioned a third hypothetical relationship with a Muslim woman named Artiga (Herculano, Alexandre, Scriptores, , pp. 180-181 ; Nobiliário Conde Dom Pedro, , pp. 4).
According to a document from Celanova mentioned in Medieval Lands
According to the Codex Roda
According to lineage books
She was added because the work mentioning the hypothetical daughter Velasquita does not cite the mother
According to document of monastery Santiago de Compostela
According to document of monastery Santiago de Compostela
According to Codex Roda
According to Codex Roda
According to lineage books

The association proposed by José Mattoso suggests that the legend of Gaia could be related to him, but it is important to recognize that there is no documentation proving this connection to Ramiro II (Mattoso, José, , pp. 208 ; Mattoso, José, , pp. 492 - 493)
According to António Rei
This hypothesis is raised in some works, but there are no primary sources to support it

There is no documentation or chronicles confirming this person. The hypothesis of his existence is raised to create a connection between King Ramiro II and his supposed grandson, Aboazar Lovesendes, who indeed existed, but is referred to as the son of Ramiro II in the legend of Gaia

Reflection 2: Patronymics and the Facts

When we examine documents from monasteries, the children of King Ramiro do not appear with patronymics; they are identified as Regis filius (Santiago de Compostela) or filii Regis(Sahagún). The patronymic "Lovesendes" indicates he is a son of Lovesendo. The same rule applies to "Ramires", son of Ramiro. Both names fall outside the pattern applied to princes and princesses. The "Livro Velho" and the Don Pedro seem to follow this pattern, leading us to conclude that the [possible] child was born out of official marriage. Considering there are no documents to prove the relationship, would you still add him to your genealogical tree?
According to António Rei
According to Francisco Dória
According to António Rei
According to Francisco Dória
When his father passed away, Ordoño began to rule the kingdom as Ordoño III in the year <htdate0>

During his reign, like his father, he engaged in new wars against the Muslims. After victories by Count Fernán Gonzáles in , the king sacked Lisbon and secured an advantageous peace with the caliph (Brito, Bernardo de, , fl. 386 - 389 ; Medieval Lands, ; Sevilla-Quiñones, Margarida T, Real Academia de la História).

Ordoño had only one son, but it is not possible to confirm if the mother was his wife Urraca. There is also the possibility that the son was the child of a daughter of Pelayo Gutierrez (Medieval Lands, ; Sevilla, Margarita Torres, Real Academia de la História). Given this scenario, we will include two [possible] wives and connect the son to an Unknown person
According to a document from Santiago de Compostela
According to studies presented on Medieval Lands
According to studies presented on Medieval Lands
According to various studies based on primary sources presented on Medieval Lands
It is also possible to find in Spanish literature named as Bermudo, he began ruled the kingdom in the year of <htdate0> as Vermudo II, el Gotoso

He had a government with external wars and also a civil war (Medieval Lands, ; Sevilla, Margarita Torres, Real Academia de la História).

His personality is defined in different ways by chronists. The Sampiro chronicle defines him as prudens [translation: prudent], while Regum Legionensium chronicle defines him as "foolish and a tyrant in everything he did" (Crônica de Sampiro, Espanha Sagrada Vol. XIV, , pp. 466 . ; Medieval Lands, )
According to different researchers
According to a document in Santiago de Compostela church
We know Vermudo II had children with an unkown person, so we added this person to link with Vermudo
According to Historia de rebus Hispaniae

He was the fourth child of Vermudo II and the third from his second marriage, but as the first son, he began to rule León in the year <htdate0> as Alfonso V while still very young. For this reason, he had Count Menendo Gonzáles as his tutor

source.text: del Pozo, José Maria F., Real Academia de la História

history.text:
Regarding the life of Alfonso V, Romualdo Escalona provides only a few details about his stay at the Sahagun monastery (Escalona, Romualdo, , pp. 53 - 56). The civil wars are detailed on the Real Academia de la Historia website (del Pozo, José Maria F., Real Academia de la História).

The death of Alfonso V is reported in the Salterio chronicle written in , and the precise location of the event, Viseu in Portugal, is described in the Church of San Juan de León (Risco, Manuel, , pp. 253 ; Medieval Lands, )
According to document in the Santiago de Compostela church
According to document in Santiago de Compostela church
She was added to establish a connection with a hypothetical son described in a lineage book
According to Pelayo chronicle
According to Pelayo chronicle
Hypothesis proposed by researchers and described on the Medieval Lands website
According to Dom Pedro
He began to rule the Kingdom of León in <htdate0> as Vermudo III

It is reported that he had three marriages in a short period of time. Like his father, he also began ruling the kingdom at a very young age. Aware of this situation, Sancho III invaded León to expand his own realm. One of the consequences of this war was the marriage between Sancho III's son, Fernando, and Vermudo III's sister. Years later, after reconquering part of his kingdom, Vermudo III was defeated by his brother-in-law Fernando, who declared himself King of León. This event marked the end of the patrilineal descendants of Alfonso III the Great (Escalona, Romualdo, , pp. 56 - 57 ; Medieval Lands, )
According to document in Santiago de Compostela church
According to document in Santiago de Compostela church
According to document in Santiago de Compostela church
She is mentioned because it is not possible to identify Alfonso's mother
According to a chronicle mentioned in Medieval Lands

exercise_v2.question: Does the lineage proposed by Don Pedro for Ordoño II include more people than the contemporaneous chronicles of Ordoño's ancestors? Is this the reason Don Pedro is considered correct?
exercise_v2.additionalInfo: When we decide that our family tree must include as many people as possible, a common mistake is to choose the path with the most individuals, regardless of evidence. The lineage proposed by Don Pedro appears to be incorrect when we examine primary sources, as these contemporaneous sources are more reliable than a nobiliary written centuries later.

exercise_v2.question: Is Lovesendo Ramires the most well-documented son of Ramiro II with his wife Ortega/Artiga?
exercise_v2.additionalInfo: The Gaia legend mentions an Aboazar who, by patronymic, could be named Aboazar Ramírez. However, upon examining available historical documents, we conclude that there was an Aboazar Lovesendes, a figure José Mattoso associates with the legend of Gaia (Mattoso, José, , pp. 208 ; Mattoso, José, , pp. 492 - 493). Lovesendo Ramires has only recently appeared in some studies, seemingly to address the issue with the patronymic (Geneall, ; Rei, António, ).

exercise_v2.question: Is determining family relationships during the Kingdom of León complex and requires analysis of various documents?
exercise_v2.additionalInfo: During the Kingdom of León, there were no IDs like we have today, so it is necessary to use various chronicles and documents to discover ancestry. Some chronicles contemporaneous to the people are contradictory, adding another layer of complexity. To make matters worse, lineage books written centuries after the events often attempted to create a legitimate lineage, establishing relationships described as facts without any supporting chronicles or documents.

exercise_v2.question: Did the firstborn children of the Kings of León typically have the same name as their parents?
exercise_v2.additionalInfo: It is common to hear that when we do not know the names of the parents in ancient times, and the person in question is the first child of a couple, this person is assumed to have the father's or mother's name. However, the case of the kings of León shows that this is a weak rule and cannot be accepted as a general guideline.
